comments.commentBody: Or Chinese help the same with Taiwan? Japan? Or any NATO country, including Turkey?

North Korea is not a world threat, it has never invaded anyone, the mere idea is ridiculous. There are two Koreas because of the imposition of the US, this was the cause of many deaths. The only reason NK has a nuclear program is because they have to defend against US aggression. The real world threat is the US, it has always been, it holds half of the mexican territory and that goes unmentioned as well as a thousand other crimes because it holds its power with military strength and it's always itching to use it. What is even more frightining is when you see that is not only the goverment but also the civil population who think they have right to destroy a whole nation ; how many children, women, elders and men in NK? But as the indians they have to be exterminated before they atack the peaceful americansi. It's a "reasonable" decision by a civilized people.
Yes as Noam Chomsky has stated on many occasions, the US is the greatest threat to world peace. Enough already.

Strange. We once again find our global security alarmingly dictated by nothing more than simple geography. The situation isn't really unusual but I tend to forget the basics every once in a while. North Korea exists because North Korea has mountains and caves. There's not much more to it than that.

We can talk about geo-politics and the Korean War. They are certainly relevant. More appropriately though, we should be talking about the continuing Sino-American War. North Korea is the small cog in the larger and more ancient Chinese, Japanese, and Russian struggle. The US jumped into the fray when we denuded Japanese military influence.

If you think about it though, every major conflict has been decided by a combination of technology, resources, and geography. By resources, I mean many things so please take the term loosely. My point though: geography traditionally defines the latter forces. Even an ICBM, right? You need to get the missile some place.

Now I'm not so sure. There are limitations to any cyber arsenal but I think we have a larger concern than a nuclear North Korea. Mr. Kim might prove the flash point but imagine a massive military conflict where geography mostly doesn't matter. What does the Monroe Doctrine even mean when networks are weapons? We've gone beyond cloak and dagger, supply chain espionage.

I wonder if we're messing with Pandora's box right now.

We and the South Koreans can handle it. It worked for West and East Germany. Let's put our State Department to work. It would be lots cheaper than a military solution. But I see my thoughts only got 2 recommends. Sigh.

@Andre: Yes SK and China have become closer economically in recent years, but there is no question that SK is much more friendly toward the US than to China. You can chalk that up to historical tensions between China and SK, SK's fear of Chinese regional hegemony, generally close relations between the US and SK for the last half-century, SK appreciation for the US role in 1950-53, etc., all of which trump economic concerns. As for the popularaity of SK music in China, tell that to Sumi Jo.

Dream on. Those who know NK know that the family's number one priority is. maintaininv power. You would as well suggest that Putin might turn Russia over to Germany in exchange for $100 billion.
This is not the way things work in Korea, and the sooner we accept that there's no neat solution -- the train for a nuclear-free N Korea left some time ago -- the sooner we Dan d envelop a rational policy. See the discussions that Plowshares sponsors on this
Too busy focusing on climate change, which former Secretary of State Kerry said was as big a threat as Islamic terrorism.

Never cared for the foodie millennial  style of the Obama's. In fact, the moment Michelle Obama started messing with all American school lunches it was over for me with that presidency.  Great to have a president who appreciates a good hamburger with ketchup (rather than catsup).

Yeah, but Michelle's school food thing is actually working out. The weight of American kids has started to come down. What's wrong with serving fresh fruit and veggies in schoo anyway ? Do you really want your child to have frozen reheated pizza and soda for lunch, or don't you care? Or maybe it's because you secretly resent Mrs. Obama for making better choices for your kids than you did.
American adults, however, are still too fat and the great Trumpkin is not setting a good example. Even Ivanka has said she wishes her father would eat better. I guess Mr. Bruni can call Ivanka Trump a food snob.
Michelle Obama was trying to do something about the appalling state of the health of Americans, focusing on our most vulnerable citizens. We are lucky the Obamas care about people.

@Wolf
Foodie millennial style?
Michele Obama was an outstanding role model with growing and tending a healthy garden, exercising, hydrating properly, and learning optimal food groups.
Trump is just burping his way thru that hamburger and this presidency.
I see no role models in that family whatsoever. I certainly don't see a loyal family man.

When two people (Trump & Kim Jong Un) with almost similar temperament rule countries, the result will be punishing for its people. Both sides should be pragmatic in their approach.

North Koreans are devastated under the family rule of dictators. The number of defectors prove this point. Long lasting solution could be met only through negotiations. There is no use wasting billions on cyber attacks. The key to this solution remains in negotiating table. When the sole super power is ready to deal with North Koreans through cyber attacks and even militarily, will it not be possible for it to figure out a way to negotiate? Where there is a will, there is a way.

Dealing with Iran was totally different. Iran cannot be compared with North Korea. Iran at least has a democratic set up, though its human rights record is bad, and its leaders were willing to negotiate.

While I do believe that Beijing holds its nose and alternately is amused when N. Korea baits the West, I doubt that it would give up N. Korea to the West. And the West is not going accept S. Korea being swallowed up into China and therefore expanding their presence and influence in Asia.

Unless N. Korea aims its missiles at Beijing, there is no incentive to lose or invade the mad, ugly little country, politics-wise. Shows a lack of strength to the outer world. And I am sure that N. Korea knows it's boundaries.

Wait a minute. You can lead a Trump to water, but you can't make him drink. He can't be bothered with intel. He's said as much on several occasions. He goes by intuition and, apparently, the divination of Fox 'News.'

Don't worry. Trump is going to ignore any objections to his use of nuclear weapons in 'negotiating' with anyone, particularly North Korea.

He hasn't seen war, hasn't learned anything except a Reader's Digest level of narratives, and evidently his zero compassion for his enemies. The latter are people who disagree with him. Trump is basically a maniac. Not a lot different than Kim Jong-un.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
The oldest four missile submarines each carry more than enough conventional arms to reduce Nork nuclear plants and weapons to so much ash. We probably won't just because they belong to Red China, but if push comes to shove, the little fat dude is a goner.

Maybe this is what Loretta Lynch is talking about. She has called for more blood and death on our streets - and the big-gov't party put her babblings on its website ''for inspiration.''
Loretta Lynch may be talking, but it's not to Russian Ambassadors, and then lying about it under oath.
Nothing said in a conversation with Al Frankin in possession of a phony dossier should be of consequence.

The North Korean leadership is not suicidal. Self preservation and a luxurious lifestyle are their foremost concerns. They're also smart and well prepared against preemptive military action. Finding mobile nuclear missiles would be near impossible, and they already have vast numbers of conventional weapons holding the South Korean populace hostage.

Developing a nuclear capable ICBM is risky but meant to extort yet more concessions from the West. This will escalate tensions but might finally provoke drastic countermeasures. The fundamental risk is that events will spin out of control resulting in mass casualties.

China wants a stable Korean Peninsula without a US ally right on their border. Reunification of the two Koreas is off the table, but a change in regime might soon be preferred by all outside parties. The simplest, cheapest, and most orderly mechanism would be to pay off the current leadership to go into exile. China could force things by threatening complete economic isolation or a coup, (but risking collapse or starvation in the North).

New leadership in a demilitarized North could be vetted by China with a new balance of power that satisfies regional powers. A newly re-industrialized North off a permanent war footing would be more stable and self sufficient, and could probably cover the costs of removing the Kim dynasty from power.

Unfortunately, the lack of god-like adoration in exile probably means we're stuck with the Kim's and potential catastrophe.

I hope, I hope that Trump doesn't think that 4 well placed hydrogen bombs would rid the world of this menace. He'd need China's permission and would have to agree for US military to leave S. Korea and Japan etc.
Better to let China peacefully deal with. N. Korea.

Van Jones praised Trump for his paean to Ryan Owens. Good grief. What Trump did is say that the deceased Owens must be happy because he was getting a lot of applause. Somehow, I think Owens and his widow and children would be much happier if he was alive instead of getting applause because he was killed in Trump's botched Yemen raid.

I have completely lost respect for Van Jones' judgment.  Trump used the widow for his own aggrandizement.  He used her for entertainment, ego gratification, and blame shifting..  His comment about her husband being happy about the applause in heaven was horrifying.

With all due sympathy to the bereaved,  I have never understood how families suffering from unimaginable grief allow themselves to serve as political props during Presidential addresses to the U.S. Congress - that citadel of hypocrisy.

How about all the other widows and widowers and parentless children resulting from Cheney and W's foray into the Middle East?  And Just how much money was it that Cheney made on his Halliburton stock with the profits from all those no-bid contracts?  And did America ever witness the pain of the family whose son died from electrocution while taking a shower in one of those Halliburton built, faultily wired, barracks buildings?

And what makes the US so sure that our advisories do not have a 'left of launch' program against our missiles. Why do we feel safe with our missile defense systems. We are only half a step ahead of the world, they will all catch up.

comments.userLocation: Fair Verona where we lay our scene
comments.commentBody:
The Awesome Coolness Dude, Barack Prince of the World, was so afraid of our enemies that they rolled him constantly, taking advantage of his dismal ignorance of international affairs.
As a result, the Red Chinese, Iranian, Russian, and other tyrants had a chance to do whatever hey wanted for eight dismal, lethal years.
Hopefully we learned a lesson - to never choose a leader based on his newsworthy looks and how much losers adored him.
Who needs a president whe we have the internet, right?

@George Heiner. It's a sad commentary but I think the US foreign policy and intelligence establishment considers Trump a more existential threat to the country than Kim Jong Un's nuclear ambitions. Not to minimize the latter in any fashion, but Trump is certifiably crazy, delusional, and poorly informed. No one wants a new Korean war or a nuclear exchange initiated by a thin skinned narcissist more concerned about his ratings than national security.

Mark, can they hack the kinds that you still have to crank?  If not, that's the one I want to go back to.  It's amazing what we once had, and sad that we let it slip through our fingers for a slick lie.
America... "hated even"...  but not when it comes to emigrating to it. Just open the door, and everyone comes (with their national flags, of course, to celebrate their national days).

Mr. Douthat, why mix words.  You are talking about ethic fighting.  The liberals - in their quest for more votes -  stirred hatred of European-Americans while hypocritically pretending to value civil rights.  They opened Pandora's box, and the only choices are two extremes.

"stirred hatred of European-Americans "

Not a hatred of all European-Americans - just most. Spanish-Americans and Portuguese-Americans seems to be exempt from the targeted European-Amercian cohort. Spain and Portugal are arguably responsible for a majority of the victims of New World Holocaust. Go figure.

You could easily  say that the conservatives-in their quest for more votes--stirred hatred of all other ethnic--non-European-- Americans--while hypocritically pretending to value independence, individual  initiative, and personal responsibility. And also, let's not forget the anti-semitism, anti-Islam and, general lack of acceptance of any non-christian religion touted by Republicans.  The Democrats have courted the WHOLE  America as it exists today--and not circa 1950. The Republicans (minus a little public polite lip service to the contrary) have steadfastly refused to accept the the new, evolving, America that includes whites and Christians but ALSO many other ethnic and religious groups. Trump is the last desperate  gasp of a backward looking segment of America, that has tarnished, perhaps irreparably, the image off America as a bastion of equal opportunity, equality and hope.  I just hope the country survives intact. As the US looks inward China looks outward to much of the developing world, gaining  respect and extending their sphere of  influence. Trump and conservatives are hastening the fall of the American Empire. I hope that future conservatives and republicans can live with this shame.

Boxless writes, "The liberals - in their quest for more votes - stirred hatred of European-Americans while hypocritically pretending to value civil rights. "

Name one.

Susan:

You're impressive. Is it humanly possible that someone could irrationally hate someone else as much as you hate Trump? A man who isn't suspected much less accused of genocide or even of burning an ant-hill with a magnifying glass?

Remind me never to look you up -- a parlor full of shrunken heads is not my idea of entertainment.

Actually North Korea was created by a couple of American policy analyst near the end of WWII. They simply drew a line through the middle of the country at the 38th parallel and allowed the Russians to occupy north of that and the Americans got south of that.

In 1949 North Korea donated some fighting divisions to Mao's Communist during the Chinese Civil war that ended playing an instrumental part in helping the Chinese prevail. A year later after the victory in China, those forces were back in Korea, highly trained and experienced. Dean Atchinson had recently given a speech in Japan saying the United States interest in Asia didn't extend past the Strait of Korea between Japan and Korea - a clear mistake on his part (he also did a mistake that triggered Japan to choose to decide to bomb Pearl Harbor). Kim decided that that meant that the U.S. would not bother defending South Korea. So with Mao in debt to Kim, Kim sought and got approval from Stalin to attempt to invade the south. Citing Atcheson's speach he aquiesced (after having turned Kim down several times before). Kim was correct in assessing his experienced and well trained forces created a power inbalance in his favor in 1950. He invaded the South in June 1950 and quickly overran front line forces, and Seoul, and the coordinated efforts of the North Korean army was so good that they easily overcame the first American units that they faced as well. Still by Nov 1950 it was necessary for Mao to bail out Kim.
I guess everyone has forgotten about Arugula-gate and Obama. And President Bush senior and his war on broccoli.

We remember. Both men set clear examples. of healthy behaviors in other ways. It is that disregard for health in a society that is dying from nutritional issues while he's taking away healthcare that engenders scorn in so many of us. And yes,  we have real popping corn in the pantry, from Trader Joe's, organic fruit and veggies,  but Edie's ice cream. Not a snob,  just trying to do right by my family.
@middle aged white woman: you clearly did not get that reference to President Bush (41). He HATED broccoli and wouldn't eat it. It was not about him LIKING vegetables but HATING THEM.
